Keywords: mobile-first, min-width, progressive enhancement, base styles
Description: Start with mobile styles as the default and layer on complexity for larger screens using min-width media queries.
Do: Write base styles for mobile then add min-width breakpoints to enhance for larger screens.
Don't: Start with desktop styles and override downward with max-width queries.
Code Example Bad: @media (max-width: 768px) { .text { font-size: 14px; } } /* desktop-first override chaos */

Keywords: 375, 640, 768, 1024, 1280, 1536, tailwind breakpoints, device widths
Description: Use a consistent breakpoint scale aligned with common device widths: sm(640) md(768) lg(1024) xl(1280) 2xl(1536).
Do: Use Tailwind default breakpoints (sm/md/lg/xl/2xl) consistently across the project.
Don't: Invent arbitrary breakpoints like 823px or 1117px that don't align with any design system.
Code Example Bad: @media (min-width: 823px) { ... } /* arbitrary breakpoint */

Keywords: container queries, component-level, @container, intrinsic sizing
Description: Prefer container queries for component-level responsiveness so components adapt to their container rather than the viewport.
Do: Use @container for reusable components that may appear in different layout contexts.
Don't: Use viewport media queries inside reusable components that can be placed in any container.
Code Example Bad: /* Component uses @media(min-width:768px) but is placed in a 400px sidebar — broken */

Keywords: clamp, fluid type, viewport units, responsive font-size, interpolation
Description: Use CSS clamp() to create smoothly scaling typography that transitions between a minimum and maximum size without breakpoints.
Do: Use clamp() for font-size to create smooth scaling: font-size: clamp(1rem 2.5vw 2rem).
Don't: Use fixed font sizes at each breakpoint creating jarring jumps between sizes.
Code Example Bad: className="text-sm md:text-base lg:text-lg xl:text-xl" /* step jumps */

Keywords: vh, vw, dvh, svh, lvh, dynamic viewport, spacing
Description: Use dynamic viewport units (dvh/svh) for height-dependent layouts to account for mobile browser chrome.
Do: Use dvh or svh for mobile full-height layouts to handle mobile browser toolbar.
Don't: Use 100vh on mobile which causes content to be hidden behind browser chrome on iOS/Android.
Code Example Good: style={{ minHeight: '100dvh' }} /* accounts for mobile toolbar */
Code Example Bad: style={{ minHeight: '100vh' }} /* broken on mobile — toolbar overlap */

Keywords: css grid, auto-fit, auto-fill, minmax, responsive grid, template columns
Description: Use CSS Grid with auto-fit/auto-fill and minmax() to create intrinsically responsive grids without media queries.
Do: Use grid with auto-fit and minmax for self-adapting column counts.
Don't: Hardcode grid-cols at every breakpoint when auto-fit would handle it automatically.
Code Example Bad: className="grid grid-cols-1 sm:grid-cols-2 md:grid-cols-3 lg:grid-cols-4" /* when items should just flow */

Keywords: flexbox, flex-wrap, wrapping, flow layout, adaptive
Description: Use flex-wrap to let items flow naturally to the next line when container space runs out.
Do: Use flex-wrap with appropriate flex-basis/min-width so items wrap naturally at the right point.
Don't: Use fixed widths on flex children that cause horizontal overflow instead of wrapping.
Code Example Bad: className="flex gap-4 [&>*]:w-[300px]" /* no wrap — overflows on mobile */

Keywords: stack, mobile stack, horizontal desktop, direction switch
Description: Stack elements vertically on mobile and switch to horizontal layout on larger screens.
Do: Use flex-col on mobile and md:flex-row or md:grid-cols-N for horizontal layout on desktop.
Don't: Use absolute positioning or floats to manually arrange items at different breakpoints.
Code Example Bad: className="relative [&>*:first-child]:float-left [&>*:last-child]:float-right" /* fragile float layout */

Keywords: sidebar, drawer, collapsible, off-canvas, responsive sidebar
Description: Collapse sidebar to an off-canvas drawer or bottom sheet on mobile screens.
Do: Transform sidebar into a drawer/sheet on mobile using a toggle button and overlay.
Don't: Keep a fixed sidebar visible on mobile that takes up most of the viewport width.
Code Example Good: className="hidden lg:block lg:w-64" /* sidebar */ className="lg:hidden" /* mobile toggle button */
Code Example Bad: className="w-64 fixed left-0" /* always visible even on 375px screens */

Keywords: holy grail, header footer sidebar, full layout, app shell
Description: Implement the classic header/sidebar/content/footer layout that adapts from single column on mobile to multi-column on desktop.
Do: Use CSS Grid template areas that rearrange from single-column mobile to multi-column desktop.
Don't: Use nested floats or absolute positioning to achieve multi-column layouts.
Code Example Bad: /* Nested divs with float:left, float:right, clear:both — fragile and breaks on resize */

Keywords: masonry, pinterest, waterfall, columns, responsive masonry
Description: Implement masonry/waterfall layouts that reduce column count on smaller screens.
Do: Use CSS columns or a masonry library with responsive column counts that decrease on mobile.
Don't: Use a fixed column count masonry layout that creates extremely narrow columns on mobile.
Code Example Bad: className="columns-4" /* four 94px columns on a 375px screen — unreadable */

Keywords: container layout, @container, component grid, adaptive component
Description: Use container queries to switch component layout based on available width not viewport.
Do: Wrap components in a container context and use @container to adapt internal layout.
Don't: Rely solely on viewport breakpoints for layout changes inside reusable components.
Code Example Bad: /* Sidebar card uses md:grid-cols-2 but sidebar is only 320px — layout breaks */

Keywords: subgrid, nested grid, alignment, consistent columns
Description: Use CSS subgrid to let child elements participate in a parent grid for consistent alignment across cards.
Do: Use subgrid on child elements so nested content aligns to the parent grid tracks.
Don't: Manually set matching heights/widths on nested elements to fake grid alignment.
Code Example Bad: /* Setting fixed height on every card section to force alignment — breaks with dynamic content */

Keywords: fluid font, responsive text, viewport scaling, type scale
Description: Scale font sizes fluidly between breakpoints using clamp() or Tailwind's fluid utilities.
Do: Use a fluid type scale where all heading levels scale proportionally from mobile to desktop.
Don't: Set completely different type scales at each breakpoint with no relationship between them.
Code Example Bad: className="text-xl md:text-2xl lg:text-4xl xl:text-6xl" /* ratio changes wildly at each bp */

Keywords: line-height, leading, readability, text block, paragraph
Description: Adjust line-height relative to font size and line length so text remains readable at all screen widths.
Do: Use tighter line-height (1.4-1.5) on mobile and slightly looser (1.6-1.75) on wider screens where line length increases.
Don't: Use a fixed line-height like 24px across all breakpoints regardless of font size changes.
Code Example Bad: style={{ lineHeight: '24px' }} /* fixed px line-height with fluid font-size — broken ratio */

Keywords: heading, h1-h6, scale ratio, hierarchy, type ramp
Description: Maintain clear heading hierarchy at all sizes with proportional scaling between levels.
Do: Maintain consistent heading ratios (e.g. 1.2x between levels) that compress slightly on mobile.
Don't: Use massive desktop heading sizes that dominate mobile screens or compress hierarchy too much.
Code Example Bad: className="text-6xl" /* 60px heading on a 375px screen — two words per line */

Keywords: truncation, ellipsis, overflow, line-clamp, text-overflow
Description: Truncate overflowing text with ellipsis rather than letting it break layouts on small screens.
Do: Use line-clamp or text-ellipsis to handle overflow with visual indication of truncated content.
Don't: Let long text overflow its container or break layout structure on narrow screens.
Code Example Bad: className="whitespace-nowrap" /* without overflow handling — horizontal scroll */

Keywords: measure, ch units, max-width, readability, line length, prose
Description: Constrain text blocks to a readable line length (45-75 characters) on wide screens.
Do: Set max-width on text containers using ch units or Tailwind prose to maintain 45-75ch line length.
Don't: Let paragraph text span the full width of a 1440px viewport creating 150+ character lines.
Code Example Bad: className="w-full px-4" /* text spans 1400px on desktop — unreadable */

Keywords: srcset, sizes, responsive image, resolution switching, art direction
Description: Serve appropriately sized images for each viewport to avoid downloading oversized assets on mobile.
Do: Use srcset and sizes attributes to let the browser choose the optimal image resolution.
Don't: Serve a single 2400px wide image to all devices including mobile on 3G connections.
Code Example Bad: /* 2.4MB image downloaded on every device */

Keywords: picture, source, art direction, crop, aspect ratio, media
Description: Use the <picture> element to serve different image crops or aspect ratios at different breakpoints.
Do: Use <picture> with <source> elements to serve portrait crops on mobile and landscape on desktop.
Don't: Use a single wide landscape image that becomes an unrecognizable sliver on mobile screens.
Code Example Bad: /* 21:9 image becomes 4px tall on mobile */

Keywords: aspect-ratio, image container, layout shift, CLS, responsive embed
Description: Use CSS aspect-ratio to maintain proportions and prevent layout shift during image loading.
Do: Set aspect-ratio on image containers to reserve space and prevent cumulative layout shift.
Don't: Use fixed height on image containers causing images to stretch or squish at different widths.
Code Example Bad: className="h-[400px] w-full" /* image distorts as width changes across breakpoints */

Keywords: lazy loading, loading attribute, intersection observer, performance
Description: Lazy load images that are below the fold to reduce initial page load time on all devices.
Do: Add loading='lazy' to offscreen images and loading='eager' only to above-the-fold hero images.
Don't: Eager load all 50 images on a page causing 30MB initial download on mobile connections.
Code Example Good: /* browser handles lazy loading */
Code Example Bad: /* 50 tags all loading eagerly on page mount — 30MB payload */

Keywords: video, iframe, responsive embed, 16:9, aspect-ratio
Description: Make embedded videos and iframes responsive while maintaining their aspect ratio.
Do: Wrap video iframes in an aspect-ratio container that scales with viewport width.
Don't: Use fixed width/height on video iframes causing overflow or tiny videos on mobile.
Code Example Bad: <iframe width="560" height="315" /> /* fixed size overflows on mobile */

Keywords: hamburger, menu toggle, mobile nav, off-canvas, navigation
Description: Collapse the main navigation into a hamburger menu on mobile to save screen real estate.
Do: Collapse nav to hamburger below lg breakpoint with accessible toggle button and focus trap.
Don't: Show a full horizontal nav bar on mobile that wraps to 3 lines and pushes content down.
Code Example Good: className="hidden lg:flex" /* nav links */ className="lg:hidden" /* hamburger button */
Code Example Bad: className="flex flex-wrap" /* nav items wrap into messy multi-line bar on mobile */

Keywords: bottom nav, mobile tab bar, thumb zone, iOS, Android
Description: Place primary navigation at the bottom of mobile screens within easy thumb reach.
Do: Use a fixed bottom navigation bar on mobile for 3-5 primary actions within thumb reach zone.
Don't: Place all navigation at the top of mobile screens requiring thumb stretching to reach.
Code Example Good: className="fixed bottom-0 inset-x-0 flex justify-around py-2 sm:hidden"
Code Example Bad: /* All nav at top — user must stretch thumb to opposite corner on large phones */

Keywords: sidebar nav, drawer, sheet, overlay, responsive sidebar nav
Description: Convert sidebar navigation to an overlay drawer on mobile with backdrop and close button.
Do: Transform sidebar nav into a slide-in drawer with overlay backdrop on mobile screens.
Don't: Keep sidebar navigation always visible on mobile pushing content into an unusably narrow column.
Code Example Good: className="fixed inset-y-0 left-0 z-50 w-72 -translate-x-full md:translate-x-0 md:static transition-transform"
Code Example Bad: className="w-64 shrink-0" /* always visible sidebar leaves 111px for content on 375px */

Keywords: tabs, dropdown, select, responsive tabs, overflow
Description: Convert horizontal tabs to a dropdown select or scrollable tabs when screen space is limited.
Do: Use a scrollable tab bar with overflow-x-auto or convert to a dropdown/select on mobile.
Don't: Display all tab items in a wrapping layout that creates a confusing multi-row tab interface.
Code Example Bad: className="flex flex-wrap" /* tabs wrap to 3 rows — which row is active? */

Keywords: breadcrumb, truncation, collapsed, path, responsive breadcrumb
Description: Truncate or collapse intermediate breadcrumb items on mobile showing only first and last items.
Do: Collapse middle breadcrumb items into an ellipsis menu on mobile keeping first and last visible.
Don't: Show full 6-level breadcrumb that wraps to 3 lines on mobile screens.
Code Example Good: /* Home > ... > Current Page (middle items collapsed into dropdown) */
Code Example Bad: /* Home > Products > Category > Subcategory > Item > Detail — wraps 3 lines on mobile */

Keywords: table scroll, overflow-x, scrollable table, responsive table
Description: Wrap wide tables in a horizontally scrollable container on mobile rather than forcing squeeze.
Do: Wrap table in a container with overflow-x-auto so users can horizontally scroll to see all data.
Don't: Squeeze all table columns into 375px making cell content unreadable at 8px font.
Code Example Bad: <table className="w-full text-[8px]"> /* squished unreadable table */

Keywords: card layout, stacked, table to cards, mobile table, responsive table
Description: Transform table rows into stacked cards on mobile with labels for each value.
Do: Transform table rows into labeled card-style layouts on mobile using CSS or conditional rendering.
Don't: Display a traditional table layout on mobile where users must scroll both axes to find data.
Code Example Good: className="hidden md:table" /* table */ className="md:hidden space-y-4" /* card stack for mobile */
Code Example Bad: /* Table with both horizontal and vertical scroll on mobile — lost in a 2D scroll maze */

Keywords: column visibility, hidden columns, priority columns, responsive columns
Description: Hide lower-priority table columns on smaller screens keeping only essential data visible.
Do: Define column priority and hide non-essential columns on mobile with a 'show more' option.
Don't: Show all 12 columns on mobile making each column 31px wide with truncated data.
Code Example Good: /* Name: always visible, Email: md+, Role: lg+, Created: xl+ */ className="hidden md:table-cell"
Code Example Bad: /* All 12 columns visible at 375px — each column is 31px wide */

Keywords: sticky header, fixed header, scrollable body, table head
Description: Keep table headers visible when scrolling through long tables on any device size.
Do: Use sticky table headers so column context is maintained when scrolling through many rows.
Don't: Let headers scroll away so users lose context of what each column represents in long tables.
Code Example Bad: /* Headers scroll off screen after 3 rows — what do these numbers mean? */

Keywords: form layout, stacked, inline, form grid, responsive form
Description: Stack form fields vertically on mobile and use multi-column grid layouts on larger screens.
Do: Stack all form fields vertically on mobile and use 2-3 column grid on wider screens.
Don't: Place form labels and inputs side by side on mobile creating tiny 120px input fields.
Code Example Bad: className="grid grid-cols-2" /* two 170px wide inputs on mobile — barely typeable */

Keywords: touch target, tap area, button size, 44px, accessibility, finger
Description: Ensure all interactive elements meet minimum touch target size (44x44px) on mobile devices.
Do: Make all buttons and interactive elements at least 44x44px (48px preferred) on touch devices.
Don't: Use tiny 24x24px buttons and links that are nearly impossible to tap accurately on mobile.
Code Example Good: className="min-h-[44px] min-w-[44px] p-3" /* accessible touch target */
Code Example Bad: className="p-1 text-xs" /* 24x20px tap target — frustrated users mis-tap constantly */

Keywords: inputmode, autocomplete, virtual keyboard, mobile input, input type
Description: Use appropriate inputmode and type attributes to show the right virtual keyboard on mobile.
Do: Set inputmode='numeric' for number fields and type='email' for email to show optimized keyboards.
Don't: Use type='text' for all inputs forcing users to manually switch keyboard layouts on mobile.
Code Example Bad: <input type="text" /> /* for email/phone/number — wrong keyboard shown on mobile */

Keywords: input width, full-width, form control, field sizing
Description: Make form inputs full-width on mobile and constrained width on desktop for optimal usability.
Do: Use w-full on mobile inputs and max-w constraints on desktop to prevent overly wide fields.
Don't: Use fixed pixel widths on inputs that overflow on mobile or look lost on desktop.
Code Example Bad: className="w-[400px]" /* overflows 375px mobile and looks tiny on 1440px desktop */

Keywords: container query, component responsive, @container, intrinsic
Description: Design components that respond to their container width rather than the viewport for true reusability.
Do: Use container queries for components rendered in varying contexts (sidebars cards modals).
Don't: Use viewport media queries for components that appear in multiple different-sized containers.
Code Example Bad: /* Same card component with viewport queries: works in main content but breaks in 300px sidebar */

Keywords: @container, container-type, container-name, setup, configuration
Description: Set up container query contexts correctly with container-type on parent elements.
Do: Add @container class to parent element and use @sm/@md/@lg on children for container-responsive styles.
Don't: Forget to set container-type on the parent making @container child rules silently fail.
Code Example Bad:
...
/* missing @container on parent — rules ignored */

Keywords: cqi, cqw, cqb, cqh, container units, relative sizing
Description: Use container query units (cqi/cqw) for sizing relative to the container rather than viewport.
Do: Use cqi/cqw units for padding and font-size that scale relative to the query container.
Don't: Use vw/vh units inside components expecting them to relate to the component size instead of viewport.
Code Example Good: style={{ fontSize: '5cqi', padding: '3cqi' }} /* scales with container */
Code Example Bad: style={{ fontSize: '2vw' }} /* scales with viewport not container — wrong size in sidebar */

Keywords: container grid, adaptive grid, container + grid, responsive component grid
Description: Combine container queries with CSS Grid to create component-level adaptive grid layouts.
Do: Combine @container with grid to create components whose column count adapts to available space.
Don't: Use viewport breakpoints for grid column counts inside components placed in different-width containers.
Code Example Bad: /* grid md:grid-cols-3 in a component used in a 400px sidebar — 3 columns of 120px each */
